p: An in vitro study evaluated the analgesic potential of a methanol seed extract by assessing its affinity for three receptors involved in acute pain signaling (bradykinin, neurokinin 1, and calcitonin gene related peptide). The extract exhibited substantial binding to the bradykinin receptor, but this effect was canceled by PVP treatment, allowing the authors to speculate that it should probably be ascribed to non-specific binding of tannins or other polyphenols [ 123]. In the hot plate test on mice, leiocarposide demonstrated very similar analgesic effects to aminophenazone for the first hour, but those effects almost disappeared post-administration after the second hour [ 56].
